text: Russell Tyrone Jones (November 15, 1968 – November 13, 2004), better known by his stage name Ol’ Dirty Bastard was an American rapper. He was best known for being one of the founding members of the rap group Wu-Tang Clan. As a solo artist, he had released two studio albums. ==Personal life== Jones was an African American who had 3 children. He had problems with drug addiction, meaning he could not stop taking them. He also broke the law a lot. His convictions included attempted assault and using cocaine.allmusic profile Jones died on November 13, 2004 due to an accidental drug overdose of a mixture of cocaine and prescription drug Tramadol, just two days before his 36th birthday. ==Awards and nominations== Grammy Awards Year Nominated work Award Result 1996 Return to the 36 Chambers: The Dirty Version Best Rap Album 1998 Wu-Tang Forever (with Wu-Tang Clan) Best Rap Album 1999 "Ghetto Supastar (That Is What You Are)" (with Pras and Mýa) Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== Ol' Dirty Bastard released two studio albums before his death: Year Album 1995 Return to the 36 Chambers: The Dirty Version 1999 Nigga Please (also N***a Please) ===Singles=== Ol' Dirty Bastard had 3 singles during his career: Year Single 1999 Brooklyn Zoo 1995 Shimmy Shimmy Ya 1999 Got Your Money (featuring Kelis) ==References== ==Other websites== * Ol' Dirty Bastard's Myspace profile Category:1968 births Category:2004 deaths Category:20th-century American musicians Category:African-American rappers Category:Musicians from Brooklyn Category:American people convicted of assault Category:American people convicted of drug offenses Category:American prisoners Category:American robbers Category:Rappers from New York (state) Category:Criminals from New York City Category:Drug-related accidental deaths in the United States
title: Ol' Dirty Bastard
